intro: Alophia lahue subsp. drummondii, commonly known as Drummond's alophia, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the Asparagaceae family and is characterized by its slender, grass-like foliage and clusters of small, white to pale blue flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in full sun to partial shade. It is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, making it a drought-tolerant species. Due to its ornamental value and ecological significance, it is sometimes cultivated in xeriscaped gardens.
